result.execSummary:
The defendant Joyce M. Ziehli was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Joyce M. Ziehli is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Joyce M. Ziehli was found guilty of Theft-Business Setting >$10,000 [Modifiers: Penalty - Theft >$10,000, Penalties for Felonies-Class "G" Felony], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).
  • Joyce M. Ziehli was found guilty of Theft-Business Setting >$10,000 [Modifiers: Penalty - Theft >$10,000, Penalties for Felonies-Class "G" Felony], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).
  • Joyce M. Ziehli was found guilty of Theft-Business Setting >$10,000 [Modifiers: Penalty - Theft >$10,000, Penalties for Felonies-Class "G" Felony], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).
  • Joyce M. Ziehli was found guilty of Theft-Business Setting >$10,000 [Modifiers: Penalty - Theft >$10,000, Penalties for Felonies-Class "G" Felony], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).
  • Joyce M. Ziehli was found guilty of Theft-Business Setting >$10,000 [Modifiers: Penalty - Theft >$10,000, Penalties for Felonies-Class "G" Felony], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Court costs, surcharges and supervision fees to be paid during the term of probation.

superMiscConds.notes: NO CONTACT WITH New Glarus Home.

*Defendant shall undergo treatment and counseling as agent deems appropriate.  
*Not to have any financial responsibilities at any employing agency and not to handle any financial records other than her own personal without agent permission.
*Make regular monthly payments toward restitution as determined by agent.
*File yearly tax returns and provide a copy to agent and apply all tax refunds to restitution as directed by agent.
*File a written report every 6 months regarding income, expenses and payments toward restitution and provide to agent.

supervisions.notes: to pay 25% of prison wages toward obligations

3-30-2016 hearing
5-16-2016 hearing
Denying motion

Joyce M. Ziehli, defendant appeared in Court by phone from Elgin Correctional Institute with counsel Cole Daniel Ruby in person.
Gary L. Luhman appeared as prosecuting attorney.
Post conviction motion to compel discovery.  Parties acknowledge receipt of documents filed and decline additional comments on the record prior to the court ruling.
Court reviews facts on the record.   Defendant allegations that documents not available due to destruction.  Defendant asserts obligation of State to provide information.  State's memo to defense counsel stating not going further with discovery due to lack of exculpatory information/evidence.  State notes issue of waiver.
Court denies defendant's motion to compel discovery.  Defense has failed to show records (if available) would show a different result.  Court notes surrender of a known right as to voluntary waiver and plea.
Atty Ruby to draft order for review and signature of the court.  Atty Ruby notes for the record - the court relies heavily on State's memo re: exculpatory records.  Atty Duxstad discussed specific types of records at Preliminary Hearing, which the Court dismissed as premature at the time.
Defendants reply brief on post conviction motion to compel
reply brief to defendants post-conviction brief in support of motion to compel discovery of victims business record
defendants brief in support of motion to compel discovery

Cole Daniel Ruby appearing on behalf of defendant, Joyce M. Ziehli, who does not appear.
Gary L. Luhman appearing as prosecuting attorney.
Atty Ruby summarizes position and request for exculpatory records referencing Court order from Feb 2014.  Atty Luhman summarizes position in response - over 3200 pages deemed relevant were copied by DA office and physically turned over to Atty Duxstad.  Atty Ruby - per the court order it is the affirmative duty of the State to produce those records - regardless of relevance.   Court has read motions, but will need time to read specific cases referenced.  Atty Ruby to file response brief by April 22, 2016.  Atty Luhman possible reply by May 6, 2016.  Atty Ruby to prepare order w/notice for Judge's signature.  Atty Ruby requests DE appear in person for oral ruling but at court's suggestion agrees to video conference.  Court instructs  Atty Ruby to contact facility to arrange video conference.
